reference.title: Enabling remote JMX with no authentication or SSL

section.p: The following simple example starts the Network Server on the command line with insecure remote JMX management and monitoring enabled, using an Oracle JDK 6 or later JVM. Password authentication over SSL is enabled by default, but here these security features are disabled, to keep the example simple.

p.note: It is not recommended to disable authentication or SSL in production environments.

section.p: When you start the Network Server from the command line, it automatically installs a security manager using a basic default security policy, unless you specify the -noSecurityManager option. You may need to customize this policy to make it suit your needs. See for details.
